descriptionSet.description: A woman wearing a pink sari and a pink flower in her hair is holding two oil lamps while sitting in front of a Ganesh statue. In the background, a candleholder and architectural elements such as an archway can be seen.

hra:item.hra:value: Das, Sushil
text-en: ECM [publisher's signet]
text-en: Sushil Das..
text-en: GANESH PUJAN No. 651

description-en: A woman wearing a pink sari and a pink flower in her hair is holding two oil lamps while sitting in front of a Ganesh statue. In the background, a candleholder and architectural elements such as an archway can be seen. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: In this image, entitled “Ganesh Pujan,” also set in an indoor shrine, a woman holds two oil lamps before a seated Ganesha. The artist Sushil Das has depicted Ganesha not as a simple statue, but as a miniature elephant-headed living being, much as a Hindu worshipper might imagine an animate image to be. And here the female worshiper has turned abruptly away from the image and towards the viewer, so she can display her own beautiful form. The poster images of puja are gendered. Female worshipers make offerings to male deities. The male poster artists (for with very rare exception they have been male) seem to delight in the opportunity to portray female devotees who look, not surprisingly, like the movie stars of the period. (Richard H. Davis) (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: Contextual background of image has taken advantage of the luxury of a larger format and more complex printing capacity to convey much more: not least here are the modern lighting fixture, as well as the implication of fashionable, up-to-date accoutrements on the devotee. (Sandria B. Freitag) (gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: "Modern” accoutrements, as well as three-way relationships amongst devotee, god, and viewer distinguish these visual representations. (Sandria B. Freitag) (gs)
